name: Somnath Jyotirlinga
description: First among the twelve Jyotirlinga shrines of Lord Shiva. Located in Prabhas Patan near Veraval, Gujarat. The temple has been destroyed and rebuilt several times throughout history.
notes: First Jyotirlinga, located on the Arabian Sea coast

name: Mahakaleshwar Jyotirlinga
description: Located in the ancient city of Ujjain, Madhya Pradesh. One of the most revered Jyotirlingas, famous for its Bhasma Aarti performed at dawn.
notes: Famous for unique Bhasma Aarti ritual

name: Omkareshwar Jyotirlinga
description: Located on Mandhata Island in the Narmada River, Madhya Pradesh. The island is shaped like the Hindu symbol 'Om'. Two temples exist here - Omkareshwar and Mamaleshwar.
location: Omkareshwar Temple, Mandhata Island, Narmada River
notes: Island shaped like Om symbol

name: Bhimashankar Jyotirlinga
description: Located in the Sahyadri hills of Maharashtra. The temple is the source of the Bhima river. Surrounded by dense forests and is also a wildlife sanctuary.
notes: Source of Bhima river, wildlife sanctuary nearby

name: Kashi Vishwanath Jyotirlinga
description: Located in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh on the banks of the Ganges River. One of the most sacred Hindu temples. The temple has been mentioned in ancient Hindu scriptures.
notes: Most sacred Jyotirlinga, located in the holiest city

name: Baidyanath Jyotirlinga
description: Located in Deoghar, Jharkhand. Also known as Baba Baidyanath Dham. One of the most sacred pilgrimage sites for Hindus. The temple complex has 21 other temples.
notes: Also called Baidyanath Dham, 22 temples in complex

name: Nageshwar Jyotirlinga
description: Located near Dwarka in Gujarat, between Gomti Dwarka and the Bet Dwarka island. The temple houses a 25-meter tall statue of Lord Shiva.
notes: Near Dwarka, features 25m tall Shiva statue

name: Amarnath Shakti Peeth
description: Sacred cave shrine in Jammu & Kashmir. Throat of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: Sacred ice lingam cave, pilgrimage only in summer

name: Jwala Devi Shakti Peeth
description: Temple in Kangra, Himachal Pradesh. Tongue of Goddess Sati fell here. Famous for eternal flames.
notes: Eternal flames burning without any fuel

name: Vishalakshi Shakti Peeth
description: Temple in Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh. Earrings/Eyes of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: Located in the holiest city Varanasi

name: Lalita Shakti Peeth
description: Temple in Prayagraj (Allahabad), Uttar Pradesh. Fingers of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: At the sacred confluence of three rivers

name: Kalighat Shakti Peeth
description: Famous temple in Kolkata, West Bengal. Right Toes of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: Most famous Kali temple in Kolkata

name: Mahalakshmi Shakti Peeth
description: Famous temple in Kolhapur, Maharashtra. Eyes of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: Famous Mahalakshmi Temple

name: Ambaji Shakti Peeth
description: Temple in Gujarat. Heart of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: Famous Ambaji Temple

name: Kamakhya Shakti Peeth
description: Most important Shakti Peetha in Guwahati, Assam. Genital organ (Yoni) of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: Most important Shakti Peetha, Nilachal Hill

name: Tripura Sundari Shakti Peeth
description: Temple in Udaipur, Tripura. Right Foot of Goddess Sati fell here.
notes: Tripura Sundari Temple, Matabari

name: Padmanabhaswamy Temple
description: Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Vishnu in Thiruvananthapuram, Kerala. One of the 108 Divya Desams. Known for its Dravidian architecture and being one of the richest temples in the world.
notes: 108 Divya Desams, famous for hidden treasures

name: Bhagavathy Amman Temple
description: Temple dedicated to Goddess Kumari Amman (Bhagavathy) at the southernmost tip of India in Kanyakumari. Located where three seas meet - Arabian Sea, Bay of Bengal, and Indian Ocean.
notes: Southernmost tip of India, where three seas meet

name: Jatayu Earth's Center
description: Nature park and tourist attraction featuring the world's largest bird sculpture of Jatayu from the Ramayana epic. The sculpture is 200 feet long, 150 feet wide, and 70 feet tall, built on a rock at 1000 feet above sea level.
notes: World's largest bird sculpture, adventure activities, Ramayana connection

name: Ooty (Udhagamandalam)
description: Popular hill station in the Nilgiri Hills of Tamil Nadu, known as the 'Queen of Hill Stations'. Famous for tea gardens, botanical gardens, Nilgiri Mountain Railway (UNESCO Heritage), and pleasant climate year-round.
notes: Queen of Hill Stations, Nilgiri Mountain Railway, tea plantations

name: Kodaikanal
description: Scenic hill station in the Palani Hills of Tamil Nadu, known as the 'Princess of Hill Stations'. Famous for Kodai Lake, Coaker's Walk, Bryant Park, and misty valleys. Popular for honeymooners and nature lovers.
notes: Princess of Hill Stations, Kodai Lake, misty valleys

name: Taj Mahal
description: UNESCO World Heritage Site and one of the Seven Wonders of the World. Iconic ivory-white marble mausoleum built by Mughal emperor Shah Jahan in memory of his wife Mumtaz Mahal. Masterpiece of Mughal architecture.
notes: Seven Wonders of the World, symbol of love, Mughal masterpiece

name: Virupaksha Temple
description: Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Shiva in Hampi, Karnataka. Part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Hampi. One of the oldest functioning temples in India, built in the 7th century. Located in the ruins of Vijayanagara Empire.
notes: UNESCO World Heritage Site, oldest functioning temple in India, Hampi ruins

name: Chamundeshwari Temple
description: Famous Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Chamundeshwari (form of Durga) located atop Chamundi Hills in Mysuru, Karnataka. One of the 18 Shakti Peethas. The temple offers panoramic views of Mysuru city.
notes: One of 18 Shakti Peethas, atop Chamundi Hills with panoramic city views

name: Madikeri (Coorg)
description: Scenic hill station and district headquarters of Coorg (Kodagu) in Karnataka. Known as the 'Scotland of India', famous for coffee plantations, misty hills, waterfalls like Abbey Falls, and lush green landscapes. Popular for nature lovers and adventure seekers.
notes: Scotland of India, coffee plantations, Abbey Falls, misty hills

name: Kedareshwara Temple
description: Ancient Hindu temple in Halebeedu, Karnataka, dedicated to Lord Shiva. Built during the Hoysala Empire in the 12th century. Known for exquisite Hoysala architecture with intricate stone carvings and sculptures. Part of the UNESCO World Heritage Site nomination.
notes: 12th century Hoysala temple, intricate stone carvings, UNESCO nomination

name: Jog Falls
description: India's second-highest plunge waterfall located in Shimoga district, Karnataka. The waterfall has four distinct cascades: Raja, Rani, Rover, and Rocket. Falls from a height of 253 meters (830 feet). Best visited during monsoon season.
notes: Second-highest plunge waterfall in India, 253m height, four cascades

name: Bannerghatta Biological Park
description: Popular biological park and zoo located near Bangalore, Karnataka. Spread over 104 sq km, features safari parks (lion, tiger, bear), butterfly park, aquarium, and rescue center. Great destination for wildlife enthusiasts and families.
notes: Safari parks, butterfly park, aquarium, wildlife rescue center

name: Shivagange
description: Popular trekking destination and pilgrimage site near Bangalore, Karnataka. Hill shaped like a Shiva Linga, features ancient temples, natural spring (Ganga), and caves. Known for challenging rock climbing and stunning sunrise views.
notes: Shiva Linga shaped hill, trekking, rock climbing, natural spring
